H0.text: Physical properties are retained by the components of a mixture when they combine, such as boiling point and ability to dissolve.

H1.text: Thermal properties are retained by the components of a mixture when they keep their own identity, such as boiling point and ability to dissolve.

H2.text: Internal properties are retained by the components of a mixture when they combine, so the components keep their own identity, such as boiling point and ability to dissolve.

A3.text: Mixtures are one product of mechanically blending or mixing chemical substances such as elements and compounds, without chemical bonding or other chemical change, so that each ingredient substance retains its own chemical properties and makeup.

A4.text: Despite the fact that there are no chemical changes to its constituents, the physical properties of a mixture, such as its melting point, may differ from those of the components.

A5.text: Vapor pressures and boiling points of substances can be affected by the presence of dissolved impurities (solutes) or other miscible compounds, the degree of effect depending on the concentration of the impurities or other compounds.

A6.text: The presence of other volatile components in a mixture affects the vapor pressures and thus boiling points and dew points of all the components in the mixture.

A7.text: Petroleum jelly will dissolve in gasoline because both petroleum jelly and gasoline are non-polar hydrocarbons.

A8.text: Solubility is often said to be one of the 'characteristic properties of a substance', which means that solubility is commonly used to describe the substance, to indicate a substance's polarity, to help to distinguish it from other substances, and as a guide to applications of the substance.

A9.text: The identity of ions and the electrical conductivity of materials.
